page.title: 13THE WETHERBY WEIR PROJECT
page.content: During 1980/81 the Wetherby Town Council became concerned at the erosion of the weir on the River Wharfe. In 1982 an appeal was launched to raise money for its repair and work began in August 1982. August 7th saw the biggest single day's effort. Using a caterpillar earth-mover an entry was cut into the river from Scott Lane and 36 cubic metres of concrete, weighing 90 tonnes and costing Â£1000 were moved across the river and laid to secure two-thirds of the weir top. Four months later, at a total cost of Â£23,000 and after a great deal of hard work from a dedicated group of volunteers, the restored weir was completed. During work at low-water level a stone paved river crossing (possibly dating back 1500 years) was clearly visible under the weir.
